Controllable growth of palladium on gold multipod nanoparticles and their enhanced electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction performances Hien Duy Mai Suncheol Kim Hyojong Yoo ⁎ Department of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering, Hanyang University, Ansan-si, Gyeonggi-do 15588, Republic of Korea Department of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering Hanyang University Ansan-si Gyeonggi-do 15588 Republic of Korea Department of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering, Hanyang University, Ansan-si, Gyeonggi-do 15588, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Integration of two metal constituents into core–shell structures is an efficient strategy to prepare advanced materials for a variety of applications. The controllable synthesis of targeted bimetallic core–shell nanostructures is an important yet challenging task. Herein, bimetallic nanoparticles comprising a gold multipod nanoparticle (GMN) core and distinctive Pd shell (GMN@Pd NPs) are successfully synthesized in a facile and controllable manner. Epitaxial or islanded growth of Pd on the GMNs can be readily achieved using appropriate stabilizing agents. The controllable growth mode of the Pd layers, coupled with the unique topologies of GMNs, are advantageous for enhancing the density of active interfacial surfaces in the composites. Particularly, I-GMN@Pd NPs show substantially enhanced ORR activity compared with monometallic counterparts and excellent durability and better tolerance to the crossover effect than that of Pt/C, rendering the materials highly desirable for practical use. Keywords Core–shell nanostructure Gold multipod nanoparticle Palladium layer Oxygen reduction reaction Nanocatalyst 1 Introduction Controllable integration of two metal constituents into bimetallic core–shell nanostructures with desirable size, morphology, and composition is considered to be quite expedient for a wide variety of applications such as catalysis [1–12]. In general, the preparation of bimetallic nanostructures can be accomplished through either simultaneous reduction of metallic precursors or the successive growth of secondary materials on the as-prepared seed nanocrystals [1]. In both approaches, regulation of the kinetic and thermodynamic parameters is critical for effectively tailoring the growth of shell architectures [13–15]. Furthermore, the heterogeneous interfacial surfaces and complex electronic interactions between the two components in bimetallic nanosystems often account for more pronounced catalytic properties relative to those of the monometallic counterparts [12,16–19]. Therefore, the ability to control the deposition of secondary materials to form nanostructures possessing desired core–shell architectures and a high density of catalytically active interfaces is an important yet challenging task. Among various bimetallic nanoparticles, Au and Pd represent an interesting combination of noble metals for the construction of hetero-structures owing to their excellent optical and catalytic activities [13,20–23]. For example, a number of studies are being conducted using Au nanoparticles with different morphologies (e.g., spheres [20,22,23], cubes [24], nanorods [25] and octahedral [21]) as cores for the growth of Pd shells. The properties of Au-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles are strongly dependent on the size and shape of the particles, as is the case in monometallic analogues, and on the core-to-shell composition [26,27]. Therefore, well-established synthetic paradigms for the controllable growth of Pd on Au seeds to achieve targeted geometries, interfacial surfaces, and spatial arrangement of the constituent domains of the bimetallic nanostructures are highly desirable for targeted applications. Recently, our group successfully developed a facile method for the high-yield fabrication of star-shaped gold multipod nanoparticles (GMNs) containing multi-branches with sharp edges and tips [28]. Importantly, the inherited anisotropic multipod morphologies of the GMNs possess curvatures and rough surfaces that could be advantageous for increasing the catalytically active core–shell interfaces during growth with secondary materials [12,29–31]. Herein, we report the effective and controllable synthesis of bimetallic nanoparticles comprising a GMN core and Pd shell (GMN@Pd NPs). More specifically, the dimensions and architectures, including the single-crystalline epitaxial or islanded growth of Pd, can be readily controlled using stabilizing agents of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAC). This is an unusual example of bimetallic nanoparticles with preserved anisotropic morphologies inherited from the GMN cores and Pd shells with finely tuned architectures. Examination of the bimetallic nanoparticles in the electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) reveals a strong relationship between the catalytic performance and the Pd layers grown on the GMNs. The bimetallic nanocrystals with islanded Pd nanoparticles (I-GMN@Pd NPs) also show substantially enhanced ORR catalytic activity compared with those of the individual GMNs and Pd nanomaterials. Interestingly, I-GMN@Pd/C shows better durability and tolerance to the crossover effect than commercial Pt/C, which renders the composite highly desirable for use in direct methanol alkaline fuel cells. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, CH3(CH2)15N(CH3)3Br, 99+%, Acros Organics), cetyltrimethylammonium chloride solution (CTAC, CH3(CH2)15N(CH3)3Cl, 25 wt in H2O, Sigma-Aldrich), polyoxyethylene glycol dodecyl ether ((C2H4O)23C12H25OH, Brij35, Acros Organics), hydrogen tetrachloroaurate trihydrate (HAuCl4·3H2O, 99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), silver nitrate (AgNO3, 99+%, Sigma-Aldrich), L-ascorbic acid (AA, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich), sodium salicylate (NaSal, 99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich), trisodium citrate (99%, Sigma-Aldrich), sodium borohydride (NaBH4, 99.995+%, Sigma-Aldrich), palladium(II) chloride (PdCl2, 99+%, Sigma-Aldrich), potassium iodide (KI, 99+%, Sigma-Aldrich), ethyl alcohol (CH3CH2OH, 99.9+%, Burdick & Jackson), potassium hydroxide (KOH), hydrochloric acid (HCl), nitric acid (HNO3), and acetone were used as received. All stock solutions were freshly prepared before each reaction. Prior to use, all glassware was washed with aqua regia (3:1 ratio by volume of HCl and HNO3; Caution: Aqua Regia is highly toxic and corrosive and must be handled in a fume hood with proper personal protection equipment) and rinsed thoroughly with nanopure water. 2.2 Synthesis of GMNs (gold multipod nanoparticles) GMNs were readily prepared via a seed-mediated procedure reported in our previous publications [28]. Typically, Au nanoseeds were first synthesized by adding 1 mL of NaBH4 (aq) (100 mM) into a solution containing HAuCl4 (aq) (1 mL, 10 mM), sodium citrate (aq) (1 mL, 10 mM), and nanopure water (36 mL). Then, the resulting mixture was vigorously stirred for 1 min and aged for 2–4 h. For the preparation of GMNs, two growth solutions were prepared (solution (A): a mixture of Brij35 (aq) (1 mL, 200 mM), CTAB (aq) (1 mL, 100 mM), HAuCl4 (aq) (80 μL, 10 mM), AgNO3 (aq) (10 μL, 5 mM), sodium salicylate (aq) (200 μL, 50 mM), and L-ascorbic acid (aq) (20 μL, 100 mM); solution (B): the mixture of Brij35 (aq) (10 mL, 200 mM), CTAB (aq) (10 mL, 100 mM), HAuCl4 (aq) (800 μL, 10 mM), AgNO3 (aq) (100 μL, 5 mM), sodium salicylate (aq) (2 mL, 50 mM), and ascorbic acid (aq) (200 μL, 100 mM)). To initiate the formation of GMNs, the as-prepared Au seed colloidal solution (100 μL) was added into solution (A). Next, 100 μL of this mixture was quickly added to solution (B). The resultant reaction mixture was then shaken vigorously for more than 1 min, followed by aging for 8 h. Upon the reaction completion, the resultant GMNs were collected by three repeated cycles of centrifugation (10 min, 6,000 rpm). GMNs acquired from each synthesis were used for the preparation of GMN core-Pd shell nanohybrids. 2.3 Synthesis of E-GMN@Pd (GMN core–epitaxial palladium shell bimetallic nanoparticles) The E-GMN@Pd NPs were synthesized by the controllable growth of an epitaxial Pd shell on the as-prepared GMN seeds in the presence of CTAB. In a typical experiment, 1 mL of the as-prepared GMN suspension (0.3448 µmol) was initially collected, centrifuged (6000 rpm, 10 min), and redispersed in CTAB (aq) (1 mL, 100 mM). To this GMN solution was added 1 mL of H2PdCl4 (aq) (0.69 mM, 0.69 µmol, corresponding to a Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratio of 2:1), followed by the addition of L-ascorbic acid (aq) (1 mL, 13.79 mM, corresponding to a Pd2+/L-ascorbic acid molar ratio of 1:20) at room temperature. The mixture was shaken vigorously and reacted at 60 °C for 14 h. After completion, the resultant E-GMN@Pd NPs were centrifuged (5 min, 13000 rpm) and purified by repeated washing with deionized (DI) water, and redispersed in DI water for characterization. The thickness of the epitaxial Pd shell could be readily controlled by varying the concentration of H2PdCl4 (aq) (0.17, 0.34, 0.52, 0.69, 1.72, 3.45, 6.90, and 13.79 mM, corresponding to Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios of 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 5.0, 10.0, 20.0, and 40.0, respectively). The concentration of L-ascorbic acid in each trial was adjusted in proportion to the amount of H2PdCl4 (aq) in order to maintain a Pd2+/L-ascorbic acid molar ratio of 1:20. Other reaction conditions were not changed. The obtained E-GMN@Pd NPs with various Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios are denoted as E-GMN@Pd(x), where x (0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 5.0, 10, 20, and 40) represents the corresponding Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios. 2.4 Synthesis of I-GMN@Pd (GMN core–islanded palladium shell bimetallic nanoparticles) The deposition of islanded Pd nanoparticles on the as-prepared GMN seeds to form I-GMN@Pd was carried out by a similar procedure as E-GMN@Pd, except that CTAC (100 mM) was used in place of CTAB (100 mM). Typically, the as-prepared GMN suspension (1 mL, 0.3448 µmol) was collected, centrifuged (6000 rpm, 10 min), and redispersed in CTAC (aq) (1 mL, 100 mM). To this GMN solution was added 1 mL of H2PdCl4 (aq) (0.69 mM, 0.69 µmol, corresponding to a Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratio of 2:1), followed by the addition of L-ascorbic acid (aq) (1 mL, 13.79 mM, corresponding to a Pd2+/L-ascorbic acid molar ratio of 1:20) at room temperature. The mixture was shaken vigorously and reacted at 60 °C for 14 h. After completion, the resultant I-GMN@Pd NPs were centrifuged (5 min, 13000 rpm) and purified by repeated washing with deionized (DI) water, and redispersed in DI water for characterization. The Pd shell thickness of I-GMN@Pd NPs could be controlled using appropriate H2PdCl4 (aq) (0.17, 0.34, 0.52, 0.69, and 1.72 mM, corresponding to Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios of 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, and 5.0, respectively). The concentration of L-ascorbic acid in each trial was adjusted proportionally with the amount of H2PdCl4 (aq) used in order to maintain a Pd2+/L-ascorbic acid molar ratio of 1:20. Other reaction conditions were not changed. The obtained I-GMN@Pd NPs with various Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios are denoted as I-GMN@Pd(x) NPs, where × (0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, and 5.0) represents the corresponding Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios. 2.5 Electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) All electrochemical measurements were carried out using a COMPACTSTAT.h analyzer (Ivium Technologies) in a typical three-electrode setup at ambient temperature (~25 °C). A Pt wire and Ag/AgCl were employed as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. A glassy carbon rotating disk electrode (RDE) and rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) with a similar diameter of 4 mm were served as the substrate for the working electrode. Prior to the measurements, the RDE and RRDE were thoroughly polished with 1.0 µm diamond and 0.05 µm Al2O3 suspensions and washed several times with DI water. In this study, the electrode potentials measured vs. Ag/AgCl were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale on the basis of the Nernst equation as follows: (1) E R H E = E A g / A g C l o + E A g / A g C l + 0.059 p H where E R H E is the converted potential vs. RHE, E A g / A g C l o is the standard potential of Ag/AgCl at 25 °C (0.1976 V), and E A g / A g C l is the experimentally measured potential in relation to the Ag/AgCl reference electrode. The catalyst ink was prepared by combining 0.35 mg of the respective catalysts (i.e., E-GMN@Pd, I-GMN@Pd, and GMNs), 0.23 mg of glassy carbon powder (0.4 – 1.2 µm; BAS Inc.), 0.067 mL of water, 0.033 mL of ethanol, and 0.011 mL of Nafion solution (5 wt%), and the mixture was subjected to sonication (10 min) to form a homogeneous ink with 60% w/w of catalyst/C. Thereafter, 8.1 µL of the prepared ink was pipetted onto the surface of the working electrodes and dried to produce a catalyst loading of 0.334 mg cm−2 for all samples. For comparison, 1.4 mg of commercial Pt/C catalyst (60% w/w Pt loading, VINA Tech Co., Ltd.) was dispersed in 0.156 mL of water, 0.080 mL of ethanol, and 0.023 mL of Nafion solution (5 wt%). Then, 8.1 µL of the prepared ink was pipetted onto the surface of the working electrodes and dried to produce a Pt loading of 0.350 mg cm−2. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out in N2– and O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH with the potential window set between 0.16 and 1.06 VRHE, at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. To obtain consistent and regular voltammograms, at least 10 CV cycles were carried out, and the data from the 10th cycle were recorded. The ORR polarization curve cycled at 0.56 to 1.06 VRHE was recorded in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 using a rotation speed of 2000 rpm. The chronoamperometric responses were measured at 0.66 VRHE in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH with a rotation speed of 1600 rpm. During the crossover tests, at around 600 s, 3.5 mL of methanol was added to 80 mL of O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH to form a 1.0 M methanol solution. The generation of peroxide during the ORR can be quantitatively measured using the RRDE method. The RRDE experiment was conducted in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH with a rotation speed of 2000 rpm; the disk potential was cycled from 0.56 to 1.06 VRHE at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 and the Pt ring potential was kept at a constant potential of 1.46 VRHE for the oxidation of peroxide. The electron transfer number (n) and peroxide percentage can be calculated from the following equations: (2) n = 4 × i d i r N + i d (3) % H O 2 - = 200 × i r N i r N + i d where id is the disk current, ir is the ring current, and N is the current collection efficiency of the Pt ring. The value of N determined by the ratio of ring and disk current in a solution containing 0.01 M K3Fe(CN)6 and 1.0 M NaCl is 0.35. 2.6 Calculation of electron transfer number for ORR The ORR polarization curve, in which the rotation speed was varied between 400 and 2500 rpm, was recorded in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. The electron transfer number (n) during the ORR was determined from the slope of the Koutecky-Levich plots according to: (4) 1 j = 1 j k + 1 B ω 1 / 2 (5) B = 0.62 n F C o ( D O 2 ) 2 / 3 v - 1 / 6 where j is the measured current density (mA cm−2) and j k is the kinetic current density; n is the numbers of electrons transferred per O2 molecule, F is the Faraday constant (96485 C mol−1), D O 2 is the diffusion coefficient (O2) in 0.1 M KOH (1.9 × 10–5 cm2 s−1), υ is the kinematic viscosity of the electrolyte (0.01 cm2 s−1), Co is the bulk concentration of O2 (1.2 × 10–6 mol cm−3), and ω is the rate of electrode rotation (rad s−1). 2.7 Characterizations The nanoparticles were imaged using a Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope (SEM), and a JEOL JEM-2010 Luminography (Fuji FDL-5000) Ultramicrotome (CRX) transmission electron microscope (TEM). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, and selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were measured using JEOL JEM-2100F microscope. Samples were prepared for TEM by concentrating the nanoparticle mixture by centrifuging twice for 10 min at 6000 rpm with resuspension in 100 mL of nanopure water and immobilizing 10 mL portions of the solution on TEM grids (Ted Pella, Inc. Formvar/Carbon 400 mesh, Copper coated). Solution pH was measured using an Orion 420 A + pH meter. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed with a RIGAKU Ultima IV diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (wavelength 1.541 Å) in focused beam and a continuous scan rate of 0.09° min−1 in the range 30–90°. 3 Results and discussions Monodisperse gold multipod nanoparticles (GMNs) with rough surfaces and multiple branches projecting outwardly (Figure S1) were synthesized via a seed-mediated protocol adapted from previous reports [28]. The GMNs can facilitate the growth of morphologically well-controlled multicomponent nanocrystals based on the star-shaped multi-branched geometry. The growth of Pd on the GMN surfaces to form uniform core–shell bimetallic nanoparticles (GMN@Pd NPs) was readily achieved in aqueous medium at 60 °C using H2PdCl4 and L-ascorbic acid as the Pd precursor and mild reducing reagent, respectively. More importantly, from the perspective of designing bimetallic nanostructures, growing different metallic constituent onto given nanocrystals in a controllable manner to achieve desired core–shell configurations is of considerable interest because the exposed heterogeneous interfacial surfaces, as well as the electronic interactions between the cores and shells, can be effectively customized [19]. Herein, we can regulate the Pd deposition to form desired bimetallic nanoparticles with distinct Pd layers by simply using appropriate stabilizing agents (CTAB or CTAC), as illustrated in Scheme 1 . The use of CTAB results in the formation of single-crystalline epitaxial Pd layer completely encapsulating the GMNs (E-GMN@Pd NPs, where E represents the epitaxial Pd). However, when CTAC is used as the stabilizing agent, a distinct configuration of bimetallic nanoparticles (I-GMN@Pd NPs, where I represents the islanded Pd) with a discontinuous shell consisting of numerous polycrystalline Pd nanocrystals is obtained. There have been no previous examples demonstrating the controllable growth of Pd shells on anisotropic multi-branched Au nanoparticles. Bimetallic nanoparticles with epitaxial Pd (E-GMN@Pd NPs) are successfully synthesized by the reduction of Pd2+ on the surface of GMN, with an estimated Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratio of 2.0, in the presence of CTAB (Fig. 1 ). The corresponding scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Fig. 1a and b) show that the original star-shaped morphologies remain unchanged, except for the uniform and epitaxial coverage of the rough surfaces of the GMNs with smooth and continuous Pd layer. The morphological stability of the GMNs beneficially imparts unique anisotropic multi-branched topologies to the obtained bimetallic nanoparticles. The epitaxial growth of Pd on the GMNs is further evidenced by the presence of alternative bright and dark stripes that cover the region corresponding to the surface of the GMN cores. These fringes are known as Moiré patterns, resulting from the superposition of two mismatched crystalline lattices (Pd (0.389 nm) and Au (0.408 nm)) that are aligned along the same direction (Fig. 1c and d) [32–34]. The crystalline structure of the E-GMN@Pd NPs is characterized by high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM). The corresponding HR-TEM (Fig. 1d (inset), 1e, S2) and Fast Fourier transform (FFT) (Figure S2) images of the outermost edge, or the tip, of a representative branch that clearly reveals lattice fringes of 2.26 and 2.35 Å, which are respectively assigned to the d-spacing of the (1 1 1) lattice planes in the crystalline face-centered cubic (fcc) structure of Pd and Au. This is in good agreement with PXRD pattern of E-GMN@Pd NPs, which reveals the presence of both crystalline Pd and Au phases (Figure S3). The dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) images and the corresponding energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping analysis of a single nanoparticle (Fig. 1f) unambiguously confirm the typical core-shell configuration of the E-GMN@Pd NPs. The EDX elemental line profiles analyzed at the main body (Fig. 1g, line 1) and furthest tip (Fig. 1g, line 2) of a branch belonging to a single particle of E-GMN@Pd NPs reveal different elemental distributions of Au and Pd and the thickness of Pd layers varies between 5 and 7 nm. Specifically, the main body of the branch (Fig. 1h, line 1) has a typical Au core-Pd shell configuration, whereas only Pd is detected at the furthest tip of the branch, confirming that the GMNs are completely covered by the epitaxial Pd layers (Fig. 1h, line 2). The estimated Pd/Au ratio on the surface derived from the corresponding XPS data is 0.68 for E-GMN@Pd (Figure S4) [35–37]. Islanded growth of Pd nanoparticles on the GMNs to form I-GMN@Pd NPs can be readily achieved by employing CTAC as the stabilizing agent. The molar ratio of Pd2+/Au3+ is estimated to be 2.0, which is similar to that used for preparation of the E-GMN@Pd NPs. The corresponding SEM and TEM images of the I-GMN@Pd NPs (Fig. 2 a and b) illustrate that the GMN seeds are collectively and uniformly encapsulated within the Pd shells and, importantly, the star-shaped multi-branched geometry of the GMN cores is largely preserved in the resultant bimetallic nanocrystals. In contrast with the E-GMN@Pd NPs, where continuous and epitaxial Pd layers are formed, noticeable deposition of discrete isolated Pd nanoparticles across the entire surface of the GMN seeds is observed in the case of the I-GMN@Pd NPs (Fig. 2c and d). The lattice fringes of 2.25 and 2.35 Å, which correspond to the d-spacing of the (1 1 1) lattice planes in the crystalline face-centered cubic (fcc) structure of Pd and Au, are also clearly observed in the HRTEM (Fig. 2e and S5) and FFT images (Figure S5). The corresponding PXRD pattern also reveals the presence of Au and Pd in the resultant bimetallic nanostructures (Figure S3). Dark-field STEM, coupled with EDX elemental mapping analysis, of a single I-GMN@Pd NP (Fig. 2f) clearly confirms that the core and shell are composed of Au and Pd, respectively. Importantly, the islanded Pd growth, coupled with retention of the multipod geometry, could provide access to nanostructures with much higher active metal-metal interfacial surfaces, which can be a determining factor in heterogeneous catalysis. The estimated Pd/Au ratio on the surface derived from the corresponding XPS data is 0.65 for I-GMN@Pd (Figure S6) [35–37]. It should be noted that epitaxial growth of a secondary material on the surface of a given ordinary material where there is a significant lattice mismatch between two materials is not an energetically favorable process due to the high strain energy [15]. The lattice mismatch between Pd (0.389 nm) and Au (0.408 nm) is estimated to be around 4.9%, which is inherently unfavorable for the formation of epitaxial Pd on the GMNs. To facilitate epitaxial growth despite the lattice mismatch, establishing a wetting film at the Au-Pd interface, which usually results from the formation of a molecular bilayer of surfactants on the surface of the seeds, and controlling the reduction of the metal precursors are critical strategies [38–42]. As shown in Figure S7, when CTAB or CTAC are omitted in the synthesis of the bimetallic nanostructures, separate Pd and morphologically irregular core–shell particles are simultaneously produced in the reaction mixture, implying that Pd growth does not occur collectively and selectively on the surface of the GMNs without stabilizing reagents. The reducibility of Pd2+ is directly related to its redox potential under the given reaction conditions, which can be tuned in a range by changing the ligands coordinating with the metal ions [15]. To further investigate the redox profiles of Pd2+, the corresponding cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Pd2+ precursors in different aqueous solutions with and without stabilizing reagents are examined (Figure S8). An cathodic peak observed at 0.178 VAg/AgCl can be ascribed to the reduction of Pd2+ (Pd2+ → Pd0) in the absence of the stabilizing reagents, which is slightly more positive than that in CTAC (0.034 VAg/AgCl). However, in the presence of CTAB, the value negatively shifts to −0.307 VAg/AgCl, implying that the reduction of Pd2+ in CTAB is more difficult than that in CTAC or in the absence of stabilizing reagents. This result could be attributed to stronger binding of Br– ions to the Pd surface in comparison with Cl– ions, which ultimately induces energetically unfavorable epitaxial growth of the Pd layer on the GMNs [33,43,44]. To further clarify the effect of the stabilizing reagents on the growth of the Pd shells, a series of experiments is conducted using varied CTAB/CTAC molar ratios. As seen in Fig. 3 , when CTAB is the major constituent (Fig. 3a–c), bimetallic nanocrystals with epitaxial Pd layer are formed as expected; however, with decreasing CTAB/CTAC molar ratios (Fig. 3d and e), the formation of discrete isolated Pd nanoparticles over GMNs is then triggered. These observations suggest the critical role of the stabilizing reagents in the growth of the core–shell bimetallic nanoparticles. Interestingly, the thickness of the Pd layer in the core–shell bimetallic nanocrystals can be readily tuned by changing the Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratio. The TEM images of the E-GMN@Pd NPs synthesized with different Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios are shown in Fig. 4 . At low Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios (≤1.0), the Pd does not fully cover the rough surface of the GMNs (Fig. 4a and 4b); however, at higher ratios (≥1.5), epitaxial Pd layer are clearly observed on the GMNs (Fig. 4c and d). The corresponding elemental mappings of E-GMN@Pd NPs synthesized with different Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios (0.5, 1.0, and 1.5) confirm the increasing amount of Pd (Figure S9). When an excess of Pd precursor (Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios ≥ 5) is used, the resulting Pd shell is much thicker (Figure S10), although a typical core–shell configuration is obtained, as indicated by EDX elemental mapping (Figure S11). Similar to the growth of the epitaxial Pd layers, the density of isolated Pd nanoparticles grown on the GMN surfaces can be controlled by varying the Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios (Fig. 5 ). The corresponding SEM and TEM images reveal that a Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratio of 2.0 is optimal for preparation of the E-GMN@Pd NPs comprising densely packed Pd nanoparticles over the surface of GMNs (Fig. 5c and f). With lower (Fig. 5a,d and b,e) or higher Pd2+/Au3+ ratios (Figure S12), either bimetallic nanoparticles with less dense Pd layers or separate Pd nanoparticles as byproducts are obtained, respectively. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra of the E-GMN@Pd and I-GMN@Pd NPs prepared using different Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios (Figure S13 and S14, respectively) show a similar trend, in which the absorption intensity of the GMNs gradually decreases with increasing thickness of the Pd shell. This is mainly ascribed to a change in the dielectric function in the presence of the Pd shells. Similar optical features have been observed for other Au-based core–shell nanoparticles [12,21,34,45]. Integration of two or more metallic materials with distinct properties often leads to advanced bimetallic nanohybrids possessing more catalytically active sites, derived primarily from the heterogeneous interfacial surfaces between the cores and shells [46–49]. Herein, the controllable growth of the Pd layers is critically related to the electrochemical performance of the obtained bimetallic nanocrystals. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is a major bottleneck of fuel cells and metal-air batteries because of its sluggish kinetics, caused by the difficulties in O2 adsorption on the electrode surface, O-O bond activation/cleavage and oxide removal [50]. To achieve desirable energy conversion efficiency, the current technologies primarily rely on the use of Pt-based nanomaterials, which are the most effective ORR electrocatalysts [19]. However, the limited available quantity and susceptibility of Pt-based catalysts to methanol crossover enormously limit their commercialization [19]. Therefore, the ORR activities of the bimetallic nanocrystals were measured to investigate their potential applications in electrocatalysis. Also, noted that the presence of surfactants (i.e., CTAB and CTAC) may adversely affect the electrochemical performance of the catalysts, we implemented different washing protocols reported previously and found that the washing procedure reported herein yield appreciable ORR activity, while maintaining the colloidal stability of the catalysts [25,51–53]. Prior to the ORR experiments, the as-prepared bimetallic nanocrystals were loaded on carbon powder functioning as the catalytic support to form E-GMN@Pd/C and I-GMN@Pd/C (Figure S15), followed by deposition of the catalyst inks on a rotating disk electrode (RDE) (catalyst loading of 0.334 mg cm−2). ORR measurements were carried out in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. For comparison, a commercial Pt/C (60 wt% Pt on carbon black) catalyst was also tested under the same conditions with the catalyst loading of 0.350 mg cm−2. The data are summarized in Table 1 . As expected, without any catalysts, the black carbon deposited on the RDE exhibited negligible ORR activity over the entire applied voltage range (Figure S16). CV curves for E-GMN@Pd/C and I-GMN@Pd/C (Figures S17 and 6a, respectively) measured in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution clearly demonstrate well-defined peaks at around 0.75 and 0.82 VRHE, respectively, which were not observed when the solution is saturated with N2, implying that these catalysts are ORR active [9,48,54,55]. The half-wave potentials for E-GMN@Pd/C and I-GMN@Pd/C are determined as 0.84 and 0.88 VRHE, respectively (Fig. 6 b). The catalytic activity of the bimetallic nanocrystals was compared with those of the individual catalyst components (i.e., bare GMNs and Pd nanoparticles) (Fig. 6b). The procedures for synthesis of the Pd nanoparticles (Pd NPs), with the mean size of 41.79 ± 8.93 nm, was similar to that used for preparation of the bimetallic nanoparticles (Figure S18), except that GMNs were not used in the former. The half-wave potential of both bimetallic nanocrystals is significantly more positive than that of GMNs/C (0.77 VRHE), indicating that the main catalytically active component is Pd-based (Fig. 6b and c). This observation is in concert with the expectation that Pd surfaces are actively involved in the ORR process. More importantly, the catalytic activity trends observed for both E-GMN@Pd/C and Pd/C differ slightly, suggesting that the core-shell configurations with epitaxial Pd layer do not effectively enhance the ORR activity (Fig. 6b). This would be ascribed to the fact that the epitaxial growth of Pd shells would somewhat conceal the functional inner Au core and moderate the interfacial surfaces in E-GMN@Pd/C. In contrast, the half-wave potential of I-GMN@Pd/C shows a noticeable positive shift of around 70 mV in comparison with that of Pd/C (Fig. 6b and c). Comparison of the half-wave potentials and specific activities at 0.9 VRHE of the aforementioned catalysts (Fig. 6c) clearly demonstrates that I-GMN@Pd/C has the best ORR performance among them. In the case of E-GMN@Pd, which has a continuous Pd covering with the thickness varying from 10 to 15 nm, the outer Pd atoms are hardly affected by the GMN core, resulting lower ORR activity. In contrast, the effective formation of small discrete Pd nanoparticles over the morphologically anisotropic GMN cores in I-GMN@Pd/C provides a higher surface-to-volume ratio of the Pd phase compared with the epitaxial Pd layers or Pd NPs. In this regard, I-GMN@Pd/C with richer interfacial surface areas results in more accessible active sites for ORR catalysis. We also investigated the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl ) by measuring cyclic voltammograms of both catalysts in a non-Faradaic region (0.94 – 1.08 VRHE) at different scan rates (20, 50, 80, 110, 140, 170, and 200 mV s−1) (Figure S19). The Cdl was determined by plotting the difference of the anodic and cathodic current density (Δj = ja - jc ) at 1.01 VRHE vs. scan rate. The obtained linear slope is twice that of the Cdl. The estimated Cdl for E-GMN@Pd/C and I-GMN@Pd/C is 88.6 and 117.7 µF cm−2, respectively, suggesting I-GMN@Pd/C possessing higher electrochemically active surface area than that of E-GMN@Pd/C. Given that optimal exposure of the active interfacial surfaces is a crucial factor for improving the catalytic efficiency, we also investigated the ORR performance of the I-GMN@Pd NPs with different thickness of Pd nanoparticles deposited on the GMNs, which were achieved by varying the Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios (i.e., Pd2+/Au3+ = 0.5, 2.0, and 5.0). As seen in Figure S20, the catalyst with a Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratio of 2.0 shows more positive half-wave potential (0.88 VRHE) and higher cathodic current density values (−5.4 mA cm−2) than those obtained with ratios of 0.5 (0.82 VRHE and −3.5 mA cm−2) and 5.0 (0.86 VRHE and −4.9 mA cm−2). The corresponding TEM images of the I-GMN@Pd NPs prepared with various Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratios (Figures 5 and S12) also confirm that at low or excessive Pd2+/Au3+ ratios, either bimetallic nanoparticles with irregular Pd layer or separate Pd nanoparticles as byproducts are obtained, suggesting that the Pd2+/Au3+ molar ratio of 2.0 is optimal for obtaining I-GMN@Pd NPs with excellent ORR activity. Rotating disk electrode (RDE) experiments at different rotating speeds for I-GMN@Pd/C (Fig. 6d) were carried out and the kinetic parameters were analyzed with the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) equation. The linearity of the K-L plots (inset in Fig. 6d) suggests first-order reaction kinetics with regard to the concentration of dissolved oxygen, and similar electron transfer numbers (n) at various potentials. The value of n at 0.70, 0.75, and 0.80 V is respectively estimated to be 3.96, 4.08, and 4.16 for I-GMN@Pd/C and 3.51, 3.73, and 4.02 for Pd/C, indicating a near four-electron transfer ORR pathway (Fig. 6e and S21). In contrast, n for GMNs/C determined from the corresponding K-L equation (Figure S22) are considerably lower than those for I-GMN@Pd/C and Pd/C (Fig. 6e), suggesting the existence of a two-electron reaction toward the formation of peroxide species (HO2 –). To further quantify the ORR electron transfer pathway, a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) experiment is conducted to detect the amount of H2O2 generated at the disk electrode during the ORR process [56,57]. The corresponding amperometric response for the oxidation of H2O2 measured with a Pt ring electrode at the potential of 1.46 VRHE is shown in Fig. 6f. As seen, I-GMN@Pd/C and Pd/C show negligible ring currents, which is two orders of magnitude less than that detected with the respective disk electrodes (Fig. 6f). In contrast, the ring current of GMNs/C increases proportionally with the disk current (Fig. 6f). Specifically, the measured H2O2 yields for I-GMN@Pd/C and Pd/C are respectively 9.3 and 9.5% at a potential of 0.7 VRHE, while that for GMNs/C is 87% (Table 1, Figure S23). The electron transfer numbers derived from RRDE data for I-GMN@Pd/C, GMNs/C, and Pd/C are highly consistent with those determined from K-L equation (Table 1 and Fig. 6e). These data unambiguously confirm the four-electron transfer ORR mechanism of I-GMN@Pd/C. The ORR mechanism for E-GMN@Pd/C is also investigated using RDE and RRDE techniques, which show a four-electron ORR pathway (Figures S24 and S25). The durability of given catalysts is an important factor for practical applications. An accelerated ORR durability test was conducted for the synthesized bimetallic nanoparticles and commercial Pt/C using the RDE technique (rotating speed: 1225 rpm) at 0.56–1.06 VRHE at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1 in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution for 2000 cycles (Fig. 7 a). After 2000 continuous potential cycles, the half-wave potential of I-GMN@Pd/C shows a slight shift (15 mV), with a specific activity loss of 4.6% at 0.57 VRHE. This is much lower than those of Pt/C, with a 25 mV negative shift and 12.5% specific activity loss, indicating that I-GMN@Pd/C is considerably more durable than the commercial Pt/C catalyst. In contrast with I-GMN@Pd/C, E-GMN@Pd/C displays poor durability in long-term ORR tests, with a negative shift and specific activity loss of up to 70 mV and 34.7%, respectively (Figure S26). For Pt-based ORR catalysts in direct alcohol fuel cell applications, minimizing performance loss due to fuel crossover must be considered, given that Pt-based catalysts are susceptible to trace amounts of fuel [58,59]. As seen from Fig. 7b, Pt/C suffers from a significant current drop after the addition of methanol to the electrolyte at t = 600 s and retains only 76% of its initial activity after 7800 s of continuous operation. On the other hand, for I-GMN@Pd/C, the current is slightly changed and quickly recovered, with 97.7% retention after 7800 s. The data suggest that I-GMN@Pd/C shows relatively good tolerance to the crossover, which is one of the important factors of the materials for the use of direct methanol alkaline fuel cells [60]. The better stability of I-GMN@Pd in comparison with Pt/C could be ascribed to the fact that poisoning reagents produced during ORR process or harsh conditions may destabilize and induce undesirable aggregation of the Pt/C. On the other hand, these phenomenon can be much supressed in I-GMN@Pd presumably due to the ligand effect of Au atoms, which also reduce the dissolution of Pd shells [9]. More importantly, gold element in I-GMN@Pd can be helpful to significantly mitigate the carbon monooxide (CO) poisoning from the methanol cross-over effect by providing better CO resistance of the Au component [9,12]. In comparison with recently reported Au-Pd based ORR catalysts (Table S1), although the ORR performance of I-GMN@Pd/C does not rank among the highest, we believe that the enhancement effect between GMN and islanded-growth Pd nanocrystals would be, to some extent, valuably contribute towards the design strategy of more efficient nanohybrids for energy-related applications. 4 Conclusions We have successfully synthesized bimetallic nanoparticles containing a GMN core and distinctive Pd shell (GMN@Pd NPs) in a facile and controllable manner. Epitaxial or islanded growth of Pd shells on the GMN cores could be readily achieved using appropriate stabilizing agents (CTAB or CTAC). The controllable growth modes of the Pd shells, coupled with the unique anisotropic multi-branched topologies inherited from the GMNs, might be significantly advantageous for enhancing the density of active interfacial surfaces, which is critically related to the electrochemical performance of the obtained bimetallic nanocrystals. A strong relationship between the ORR performance of the bimetallic nanoparticles and their distinctive Pd shells was observed. The I-GMN@Pd NPs showed substantially enhanced ORR catalytic activity compared with their corresponding monometallic counterparts. Interestingly, I-GMN@Pd/C showed better durability and tolerance to the crossover effect than Pt/C, which renders the materials highly desirable for direct methanol alkaline fuel cell applications. coredata.dc:description: Integration of two metal constituents into core–shell structures is an efficient strategy to prepare advanced materials for a variety of applications. The controllable synthesis of targeted bimetallic core–shell nanostructures is an important yet challenging task. Herein, bimetallic nanoparticles comprising a gold multipod nanoparticle (GMN) core and distinctive Pd shell (GMN@Pd NPs) are successfully synthesized in a facile and controllable manner. Epitaxial or islanded growth of Pd on the GMNs can be readily achieved using appropriate stabilizing agents. The controllable growth mode of the Pd layers, coupled with the unique topologies of GMNs, are advantageous for enhancing the density of active interfacial surfaces in the composites. Particularly, I-GMN@Pd NPs show substantially enhanced ORR activity compared with monometallic counterparts and excellent durability and better tolerance to the crossover effect than that of Pt/C, rendering the materials highly desirable for practical use.
coredata.dc:title: Controllable growth of palladium on gold multipod nanoparticles and their enhanced electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction performances
